questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding drug absorption:

options.label: B
options.text: Highly ionized molecules are absorbed from the stomach

options.label: C
options.text: Heparin is not absorbed due to its large size

options.label: D
options.text: Most common method of drug absorption is by passive diffusion

questions.correct_answer: B. Highly ionized molecules are absorbed from the stomach
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Highly ionized molecules are absorbed from the stomach High-yield concepts about absorption First-pass metabolism is inversely proportional to bioavailability, so reduces bioavailability Highly ionized molecules are not at all absorbed from the stomach or intestine or any place Heparin is not absorbed due to its large size and it is highly ionized The most common method of drug absorption is by passive diffusion

questions.text: Which of the following is a P glycoprotein inducer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rifampicin Rifampicin is used for the treatment of tuberculosis in combination with other antibiotics, such as pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and ethambutol. For the treatment of tuberculosis, it is administered daily for at least six months.

Highyeild:

Rifampin Rifampin is a semisynthetic derivative of rifamycin, an antibiotic produced by Streptomyces mediterranei. Rifampin binds to the beta subunit of bacterial DNA- dependent RNA polymerase and thereby inhibits RNA synthesis. Rifampin is well absorbed after oral administration and excreted mainly through the liver into bile. It then undergoes enterohepatic recirculation, with the bulk excreted as a deacylated metabolite in feces and a small amount in the urine. Rifampin is distributed widely in body fluids and tissues.

questions.text: Among the following extent of a drug, absorption is indicated by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Auc Auc Area under Curve (AUC) --- Determines extent of absorption

Highyeild:

Cmax is the maximum concentration attained by the drug after oral administration Time to peak (Tmax): the time after admin that it takes for the drug to reach cmax. This is an indication of the rate of absorption Both Cmax and Tmax indicate the rate of drug absorption The onset of action: The time required to reach the Minimum Effective Concentration (MEC) following drug administration Minimum Effective Concentration (MEC): minimum plasma concentration of drug required to produce a therapeutic effect. Half-life(t1/2): Time is taken by the body to reduce current Cmax by 50% (same as the time taken to achieve a 50 % increase. At 5 half live period 97% of ANY drug will be eliminated regardless of the initial concentration Therapeutic range: Between Minimum Effective Concentration and Maximum tolerated dose

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Therapeutic range is the range of drug levels in the blood of a patient in which a drug has the desired effects upon the body. It relates to a quantitative benchmark associated with proper dosage levels of prescription medications within the ser Option: D. T ½ pharmacological half-life) is the time taken for the concentration of a biological substance (such as a medication) to decrease from its maximum concentration (Cmax) to half of Cmax in the blood plasma, and is denoted by the abbreviation. This is used to measure the removal of things such as metabolites, drugs, and signaling molecules from the body

questions.text: A drug has a very low volume of distribution (Vd). Which of the following is the best explanation?

options.label: A
options.text: The drug is eliminated by the kidneys, and the patient has renal insufficiency

options.label: B
options.text: The drug is having a large molecular weight

options.label: C
options.text: The drug is extensively stored in tissues

options.label: D
options.text: The drug is eliminated by zero-order kinetics

questions.correct_answer: B. The drug is having a large molecular weight
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The drug is having a large molecular weight Factors affecting the volume of distribution (Vd): Low molecular weight drugs have high vd High molecular weight drugs have low vd Plasma protein binding High plasma protein binding decreases vd Low plasma protein binding increases vd Tissue perfusion Decreased tissue perfusion implies decreased vd Water soluble drugs have low vd and lipid-soluble drugs have high vd Tissue binding. High vd with higher tissue binding

questions.text: All are true about biotransformation except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is the chemical alteration of the drug in the body

options.label: B
options.text: The metabolites thus formed are more lipid soluble

options.label: D
options.text: There are two major phases of biotransformation

questions.correct_answer: B. The metabolites thus formed are more lipid soluble
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The metabolites thus formed are more lipid soluble

Highyeild:

Biotransformation means the chemical alteration of the drug in the body The metabolites thus formed are less lipid soluble and more water-soluble Hence not reabsorbed from the renal tubules and thus are finally excreted. SITES: Mainly in LIVER Other sites: GI tract, Kidney, Lungs, Blood, Skin, Placenta, The classification of biotransformation is given by T.WILLIAMS As PHASE I and PHASE II reaction

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It is chemical alteration of the drug in the body is a true statement Option: C. Occurs Mainly in the liver is a true statement Option: D. There are two major phases of biotransformation is a true statement

questions.text: The following statements are true about microsomal enzymes except:

options.label: B
options.text: Most of Phase I and Glucuronide conjugation of Phase II reaction are by microsomal enzymes

questions.correct_answer: A. Present In Cytoplasm, and Mitochondria
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Present In Cytoplasm, and Mitochondria Difference between microsomal enzymes and non-microsomal enzymes microsomal enzymes Non-microsomal enzymes ● Present In endoplasmic reticulum ● Most of Phase I and Phase II [Glucuronide conjugation] ● Inducible ● CYP450 ● Present in Cytoplasm, Mitochondria of liver cells and plasma ● Most of Phase II and some Phase I [Some oxidation, most reduction and hydrolysis] ● Not inducible ● Flavoprotein oxidases, ● Flavoprotein esterases, amidases

questions.text: Which of the following statement defines prodrug?

options.label: A
options.text: Active drug to an inactive metabolite

options.label: B
options.text: Active drug to the active metabolite

questions.correct_answer: C. Inactive drug to Active metabolite
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inactive drug to Active metabolite PRODRUG: It is an inactive form of a drug, which is converted to an active form after metabolism. List of prodrugs Inactive drug to Active metabolite: (Prodrug) Levodopa Dopamine Enalapril Enalaprilat - a-Methyldopa - a-methylnorepinephrin Dipevefrine Epinephrine Sulindac Sulfide metabolite Proguanil Cycloguanil - Prednisone Prednisolone Bacampicillin - Ampicillin Sulfasalazine 5-Aminosalicylic acid Cyclophosphamide and Aldophosphamide to phosphoramide mustard, acrolein Fluorouracil Fluoruridine monophosphate Mercaptopurine - Methyl mercaptopurine ribonucleotide Acyclovir - Acyclovir triphosphate

questions.text: The conversion of Diazepam to Oxazepam is an example of-

options.label: A
options.text: Active drug to an inactive metabolite

options.label: B
options.text: Active drug to the active metabolite

questions.correct_answer: B. Active drug to the active metabolite
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Active drug to the active metabolite

Highyeild:

Diazepam Indication and dose of the drug: SEIZURE DISORDERS: 0.2mg/kg repeat after 4- 12 hrs MUSCLE SPASMS:5-10mg IV/IM initially STATUS EPILEPTICUS: 5-10mg IV/IM not to exceed 30mg Sedation-Midazolam is indicated for the sedation of patients in intensive care settings, including intubated patients receiving mechanical ventilation Anesthesia, general, adjunct

questions.text: Following are Synthetic reactions in biotransformation except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reduction The classification of biotransformation is given by R.T.WILLIAMS As PHASE I and PHASE II reaction PHASE I Reactions: Non-synthetic reaction – metabolite may be active or inactive Oxidation: hydroxylation (aromatic and aliphatic) Reduction Hydrolysis Cyclization Decyclization PHASE II Reactions: Synthetic/Conjugation reaction – metabolite is mostly inactive Glucuronidation Acetylation Methylation Sulphate Glycine glutathione REMEMBER: PHASE I Reactions are also called Non-synthetic reaction PHASE II Reactions are also called synthetic reaction

questions.text: A 25-year-old married woman was on OCP for contraception and was started on a drug Y. Her UPT was positive after 1 month. Which of the following drug would have been added to her:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rifampicin

Highyeild:

CYP Inducers & Inhibitors CYP enzymes are proteins containing a heme cofactor- they are hemoproteins. They are also responsible for 75 percent of total drug metabolism. Some drugs induce, whereas other drugs inhibit, the activity of these enzymes. For example: St. Johns Wort induces activity of CYP3A4 - meaning substrates of this enzyme (such as ketoconazole) will be more rapidly metabolised. Inducers Inhibitors BULLSHIT CRAP GPS ↓ Barbiturates St. Johns Wort Carbamazepine Rifampin Alcohol (Chronic Use) Phenytoin Griseofulvin Phenobarbital Sulfonylureas SICKFACES.COM ↓ Sodium Valproate Isoniazid Cimetidine Ketoconazole Fluconazole Alcohol Chloramphenicol Erythromycin Sulfonamides Ciprofloxacin Omeprazole Metronidazole + Grapefruit Juice Amiodarone Quinidine

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Isoniazid is an antibiotic used for the treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (TB) and inactive (latent) TB (a serious infection caused by bacteria that affects the lungs and in certain cases other parts of the body). It works by killing the bacteria that cause tuberculosis. Option: C. Ketoconazole is an antiandrogen, antifungal, and anti-glucocorticoid medication used to treat several fungal infections. Applied to the skin it is used for fungal skin infections such as tinea, cutaneous candidiasis, pityriasis versicolor, and dandruff, Option: D. Erythromycin is an antibiotic used for the treatment of several bacterial infections. This includes respiratory tract infections, skin infections, chlamydia infections, pelvic inflammatory disease, and syphilis. It may also be used during pregnancy to prevent Group B streptococcal infection

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother comes to your clinic for advice regarding drug intake during lactation. What instruction do you give to a mother who is lactating?

options.label: A
options.text: No advice as most drugs are not present in breast milk

options.label: C
options.text: Systemic route of drug administration is preferred over topical

options.label: D
options.text: Just before the next dose when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

questions.correct_answer: D. Just before the next dose when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Just before the next dose when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least Instruction given to a mother who is lactating is she should breastfeed just before the next dos, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least, If the nursing mother must take medications and the drug is a relatively safe one, she should optimally take it 30–60 minutes after nursing and 3–4 hours before the next feeding.

Highyeild:

The effect of drugs on the nursing infant depends on Transfer of drug into Breast Milk The amount of breast milk consumed by the infant. The pharmacologic activity of the drug: absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination by the infant. Condition of the infant: Greater precaution for infants premature or compromised or in the first week of life than for older, healthy infants.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. No advice as most drugs are not present in breast milk Option: B. Give longer half-life drugs Option: C. Systemic route of drug administration is preferred over topical note: a,b,c is wrong statement

questions.text: Digoxin has a half-life of 40 hours, which helps in prescribing to determine:

options.label: B
options.text: Need for loading dose to give immediate effect

options.label: D
options.text: Can be given once in 2 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Need for loading dose to give immediate effect
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Need for loading dose to give immediate effect

Highyeild:

Digoxin toxicity Electrolytes Hypokalemia results in increased digoxin binding increasing its therapeutic and toxic effects. Hypercalcemia enhances digitalis-induced inotropy leading to possible Ca 2 overload and increased susceptibility to digitalis-induced arrhythmias. Hypomagnesemia can sensitize the heart to digitalis-induced arrhythmias. Hack JB. Chapter 84. Cardoactive eroids in Hack JB, ed. Goldfank's Toxicologic Emergencies ed. New York McGraw-2011 The elimination half-life of digoxin ordinarily is about 40 h( around 2 days) So the drug will take four to five half-lives( around 8 to 10 days) to attain a steady state concentration and provide therapeutic efficacy In case of life-threatening atrial fibrillation, we need immediate effect Hence we need to give a loading dose to provide an immediate effect. This is called digitalization

questions.text: Which of the following defines drug Clearance?

options.label: A
options.text: Amount of drug eliminated in unit time

options.label: B
options.text: Time required to reduce the initial plasma concentration of a drug to half

options.label: C
options.text: The volume of plasma cleared of the drug in unit time

questions.correct_answer: C. The volume of plasma cleared of the drug in unit time
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The volume of plasma cleared of the drug in unit time Clearance means a volume of plasma cleared of the drug in a unit of time

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The amount of drug eliminated in unit time is the elimination rate The time required to reduce the initial plasma concentration of a drug to half is the plasma half-life Steady-state plasma concentration is a state where the rate of drug administration is equal to the rate of drug elimination

questions.text: Loading dose depends on which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Volume of distribution Loading dose of a drug is given by the formula Loading dose = target plasma concentration X Volume of distribution / F So from the formula it is obvious that if the volume of distribution of a drug, the loading dose also increases, for example, chloroquine has high Vd( > 13,000L), so it has to be given as a loading dose of 600mg while treating malaria Note: The maintenance dose of a drug is given by the formula Maintenance dose = target plasma concentration X clearance X Dosing interval / F so from the formula, it is obvious that the Maintenance dose depends on the clearance of the drug

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about zero-order kinetics?

options.label: A
options.text: Rate of elimination of drug does not depend upon plasma concentration

options.label: B
options.text: Constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time

options.label: C
options.text: Clearance is more at low concentrations and less at high concentrations

options.label: D
options.text: Half-life is less at low concentrations and more at high concentrations.

questions.correct_answer: B. Constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time Zero-order kinetics The rate of elimination of the drug does not depend upon plasma concentration A constant amount of the drug is eliminated per unit of time Clearance is more at low concentrations and less at high concentrations Half-life is less at low concentrations and more at high concentrations

questions.text: Zero-order kinetics is shown by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Warfarin Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that helps prevent the formation of harmful blood clots in the legs, lungs, brain, and heart.

Highyeild:

The drugs whose kinetics changes from first order to zero order at therapeutic concentration are said to follow pseudo- zero order kinetics. Z ero Z ero order kinetics shown by W W arfarin A A lcohol and A spirin T T heophylline T T olbutamide P ower P henytoin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Carbamazepine is a medicine used to treat epilepsy. It helps prevent and control seizures (fits). It can also be taken for nerve pain caused by diabetes (neuropathy) or a painful condition of the face called trigeminal neuralgia. Occasionally it is used to treat bipolar disorder. Option: B. Methotrexate formerly known as amethopterin, is a chemotherapy agent and immune-system suppressant. It is used to treat cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancies. Types of cancers it is used for include breast cancer, leukemia, lung cancer, lymphoma, gestational trophoblastic disease Option: D. Paracetamol is a medication used to treat fever and mild to moderate pain. Common brand names include Tylenol and Panadol. At a standard dose, paracetamol only slightly decreases body temperature

questions.text: All are pharmacogenetic conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenosine deaminase deficiency

questions.text: Choose the right match:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gq: Phospholipase C activation Remember: Gs: Adenylyl cyclase activation Ca2+ channel opening Gi: Adenylyl cyclase inhibition K+ channel opening Go: Ca2+ channel inhibition Gq: Phospholipase C activation

questions.text: Among the following options, Nitric oxide acts by which mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased c GMP

Highyeild:

Mechanism of Nitric oxide (NO): NO activates the soluble isoform of guanylyl cyclase Activated guanylyl cyclase increases intracellular levels of cyclic GMP Increased cyclic GMP promotes the dephosphorylation of the myosin light chain and there is the reduction of systolic Ca2+ and leads to the relaxation of smooth muscle cells in a broad range of tissues The NO-dependent relaxation of vascular smooth muscle leads to vasodilation NO-mediated guanylyl cyclase activation inhibits platelet aggregation and relaxes the smooth muscle in the bronchi and GI tract

questions.text: Which of the following acts on Membrane-bound Guanyl cyclase enzyme receptor and increases cGMP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nesiritide acts on Membrane-bound Guanyl cyclase enzyme receptor and increases cGMP

Highyeild:

Nesiritide New-recombinant form of beta natriuretic peptide (BNP). Indication: refractory HF. Potent vasodilator (venous>arteriolar); decreases LV filling pressures (pre-load) and SVR (afterload); improves cardiac output. Must monitor renal function- renal failure occurs. Continuous IV infusion following a bolus. May have diuretic effects in some individuals. NO and glyceryl trinitrate (releases NO) Acts on intracellular enzyme Soluble Guanyl cyclase and increases cGMP Insulin Acts on tyrosine kinase receptor Interleukins Acts on Transmembrane JAK-STAT binding receptors

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the mechanism of action of thyroid hormones T4 and T3 at thyroid hormone receptor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Activate nuclear transcription factor T3 and T4 to act on nuclear receptors (thyroid hormone receptor). By acting on these receptors they activate nuclear transcription factors Both T3 and T4 penetrate cells by active transport and produce the majority of their actions by combining with a nuclear thyroid hormone receptor (TR) which belongs to the steroid and retinoid superfamily of intracellular receptors. Two TR isoform families (TRα and TRβ) have been identified.

questions.text: Among the following options, the antagonism seen between heparin and protamine sulfate is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chemical antagonism Antagonism seen between heparin and protamine sulfate is Chemical antagonism Heparin is a strongly negative macromolecule and protamine is a strongly positive protein. so protamine neutralizes the heparin effect by Chemical antagonism Chemical antagonism: The two drugs react chemically and form an inactive product, E.g. KMnO4 oxidizes alkaloids—used for gastric lavage in poisoning. Tannins + alkaloids—insoluble alkaloidal tannate is formed. Chelating agents (BAL, Cal. disod. edetate) complex toxic metals (As, Pb). Nitrites form methemoglobin which reacts with cyanide radicals. Drugs may react when mixed in the same syringe or infusion bottle: Thiopentone sod. + succinylcholine chloride Penicillin-G sod. + succinylcholine chloride Heparin + penicillin/tetracyclines/streptomycin/hydrocortison

questions.text: The therapeutic index is a measure of which of the following options?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Safety

Highyeild:

Therapeutic Index = Lethal Dose 50/ Effective Dose 50 Therapeutic index is a measure of drug safety Drug with a high therapeutic index is a safe example: penicillin, cephalosporins Drug with a low therapeutic index is unsafe, for example, digoxin, theophylline, TCAs Where: Median effective dose (ED50) is the dose which produces the specified effect in 50% individuals and median lethal dose (LD50) is the dose which kills 50% of the recipients

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. E fficacy (Emax) is the maximum response achievable from an applied or dosed agent, for instance, a small molecule drug. Intrinsic activity is a relative term for a drug's efficacy relative to a drug with the highest observed efficacy. Option: B. Potency is a measure of drug activity expressed in terms of the amount required to produce an effect of given intensity A highly potent drug (e.g., fentanyl, alprazolam, risperidone, bumetanide, bisoprolol) evokes a given response at low concentrations, while a drug of lower potency (meperidine, diazepam, ziprasidone, furosemide, metoprolol) evokes the same response only at higher concentrations Option: D. Toxicity is the degree to which a chemical substance or a particular mixture of substances can damage an organism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old was suffering from gastric ulcer and he was prescribed capsule omeprazole. The pharmacogenetic analysis revealed the patient is a poor metabolizer of a CYP450 enzyme. The patient may have higher exposure to active parent drugs, a greater pharmacodynamic effect (higher gastric pH), and a higher probability of ulcer cure than heterozygotes or homozygous wild-type individuals. Which of the following enzyme does omeprazole metabolize through?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CYP2C19 Several proton pump inhibitors, including omeprazole and lansoprazole, are inactivated by CYP2C19. Thus, Poor metabolizer patients have higher exposure to active parent drugs, a greater pharmacodynamic effect (higher gastric pH), and a higher probability of ulcer cure than heterozygotes or homozygous wild-type individuals.
